newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina's Catholic leaders back labor "dialogue".
newsitem.headline: Argentina's Catholic leaders back labor "dialogue".

text.p: Argentina's Roman Catholic Church expressed support for a preliminary agreement between the government and trade unions over labor reforms, local media said on Tuesday.

The Church did not comment on specifics of the deal, but in a statement issued Monday and signed by Cardinal Raul Primatesta, it said it felt under "obligation to stress the importance of social dialogue," especially in light of recent clashes between security forces and striking workers in a southern province.
After months of disagreement, the government and the CGT labor federation in early May reached a preliminary agreement on draft laws to reform the labor market, averting a general strike.
The deal is opposed by the Group of Eight business lobby, which argues it does not achieve the original aim of making labor laws fully flexible.

The pact contemplates replacing severance payments with a unemployment insurance system and changing the centralized collective wage-bargaining system to allow for some direct contacts between workers and employers.
However, it would limit open competition in health care to union-run programs, instead of allowing private health-care providers to compete for unionized workers as clients.
The government says labor reform is necessary to reduce employer costs, which would in turn help cut the country's near-record unemployment rate of 17.3 percent.
